options.label: A
options.text: Malnutrition

options.label: B
options.text: Population

options.label: C
options.text: Contraceptive failure

options.label: D
options.text: LBW

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contraceptive failure

Highyeild:

The pearl index indicates the effectiveness of a contraceptive or is an index of contraception failure. It is expressed in terms of failure rate per hundred women - years of exposure (HWY). Failure rate per HWY is denoted by- Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 (12 × 100) No. of patients observed × months of use In applying the above formula the following points must be kept in mind: The total accidental pregnancies shown in the numerator must include every known conception, whatever its outcome. The factor 1200 is the number of months in 100 years. The total months of exposure in the denominator are obtained by deducing from the period under review of 10 months for a full-term pregnancy and 4 months for an abortion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and D : are incorrect

Extraedge:

Pearl Index: WHO category 1 (user independent) Contraception Perfect use rate Typical use Implants 0.5% .05% Sterilization Male 0.1% 0.15% Female 0.5% 0.5% IUCD Mirena 0.2% 0.2% CuT 0.6% 0.8% WHO category 2 (user dependent) Contraception Perfect use rate Typical use OCP's 0.3% 8.7% Vaginal ring 0.3% 8% Transdermal path 0.3% 8% DMPA 0.3% 3% Diaphragm 20% 20%

questions.text: Which synthetic estrogen is contained in most combined oral contraceptive (COC) pills?

options.label: A
options.text: Cyproterone acetate

options.label: B
options.text: Drospirenone

options.label: C
options.text: Ethinylestradiol

options.label: D
options.text: Oestradiol valerate

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ethinylestradiol The majority of combined hormonal contraceptives contain the synthetic estrogen, ethinylestradio l. A COC product containing mestranol is also available, with 50 μg of mestranol roughly equating to 35 μg of ethinylestradiol.

Highyeild:

Oral Contraceptives Mechanism of action Prevention of ovulation Prevention of fertilization Interference with Implantation ● Progestin reduces frequency of LH secretory pulses, while estrogen primarily reduces FSH secretion. ● Both synergise each other to inhibit midcycle LH surge. ● As a result, follicles fail to develop and rupture and ovulation does not occur. ● Thick cervical mucus, hostile to sperms may inhibit fertilization. ● Uterine and tubal contractions may be modified to disfavor fertilization ● Endometrium is rendered either hyperproliferative, hypersecretory, or atrophic and out of phase with fertilization and not suitable for nidation. Thus, even if ovulation and fertilization occur, implantation does not occur normally. OCPs Can Be Monophasic Biphasic Triphasic ● Have same estrogen (E) and Progesterone (P) in 21 tablets ● First 10 pills have one dosage ● Next 11 pills have some other E and P dosage ● First 7 pills have same dosage (EE - 30 mcg, LNG-50 mcg) ● Next 7 have another dosage (EE - 40 mcg, LNG - 75 mcg) and last 7 have yet another dosage (EE - 30 µg, LNG - 125 mcg) Note: The last 7 pills (in all types of OCPS with 28 tablets) do not contain any hormone but have 60 mg of elemental iron. On the basis of the amount of estrogen, they can be classified as: Standard dose → 50 mcgEE Low dose → 35 mcg EE Very loose dose → 20 mcgEE

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Cyproterone acetate is an antiandrogen drug used for androgenic symptoms of PCOS. Option B. Drospirenone is a 4th generation Progesterone. Option D. Oestradiol valerate More recently, COC products have been introduced into the market , which contain the naturally occurring human hormone, estradiol, either as estradiol valerate or as estradiol hemihydrate.

questions.text: What is the most efficacious form of long-acting reversible contraception?

options.label: A
options.text: COC pill

options.label: B
options.text: Copper intrauterine device

options.label: C
options.text: Depo medroxyprogesterone acetate

options.label: D
options.text: Etonogestrel-containing subdermal implant

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Etonogestrel-containing subdermal implant The failure rate of the implant is 0.05 hwy (PEARL INDEX)

Highyeild:

Progestin Only Implants Subdermal Progesterone Implants Include Norplant I Norplant II/Jadelle Implanon ● It has 6 rods containing 36 mg of Levonorgestrel each ● Replaced after 5 years ● It is 3 cm long ● It has 2 rods each containing 75 mg of LNG and releases the drug at the same dose as norplant 1 ● It has a single rod 4 cms in size containing 68 mg of 3 ketodesogestrel (etonorgestrel). It is 4 cm long ● Most popular implant these days." ● Replaced after 3 years." ● Releases 60 mcg of ● hormone per day ● Doesnot decrease bone mineral density. Note: Now implanon has been replaced by Nexplanon which has same characteristic like implanon Mechanism of Action Norplant Implanon ● Thickening of cervical mucus ● Suppressing the LH surge and causing either anovulatory cycles or luteal insufficiency ● Causes endometrial atrophy ● Main mechanism is ovulation inhibition? (Remember - newer progestin only pills containing desogestrel also have ovulation inhibition as their main mechanism). ● Rest of the mechanism is same as Norplant Site of insertion Implants are inserted subcutaneously on the inner surface of the upper arm using a 10 gauge trocar as an inserter, under local anesthesia. The implant should be inserted within day-5 of a menstrual cycle, immediately after abortion, and 3 weeks after postpartum. Advantages Can be used in females with contraindication for the use of estrogen-containing Can be used immediately postpartum . Can be used by lactating females. Not associated with changes in carbohydrate or lipid metabolism. No adverse effect on bone density. SIDE EFFECT: Metrorrhagia and headache are the main reasons for the discontinuation of implants by females. CONTRAINDICATION: Absolute: Undiagnosed Genital bleeding Active Thrombophlebitis or Thromboembolic disease Known or suspected Breast cancer Acute Liver disease Benign or malignant Liver Tumours. Relative: Severe acne Severe vascular or migraine headache Severe depression Implant Systems

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. COC pill - The failure rate is 3 % to 8.7% ( it is user dependent ) Option: B. Copper intrauterine device - The failure rate is 0.6% to 0.8% Option: C. Depo medroxyprogesterone acetate -Failure rate is 0.3% to 3%.

Extraedge:

Pearl Index: WHO category 1 (user independent) Contraception Perfect use rate Typical use Implants 0.5% .05% Sterilization Male 0.1% 0.15% Female 0.5% 0.5% IUCD Mirena 0.2% 0.2% CuT 0.6% 0.8% WHO category 2 (user dependent) Contraception Perfect use rate Typical use OCP's 0.3% 8.7% Vaginal ring 0.3% 8% Transdermal path 0.3% 8% DMPA 0.3% 3% Diaphragm 20% 20%

questions.text: Which contraceptive is given free by the government?

options.label: A
options.text: COC pill

options.label: B
options.text: Copper intrauterine device

options.label: C
options.text: Depo medroxyprogesterone acetate

options.label: D
options.text: Etonorgestrel-containing subdermal implant

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Depo medroxyprogesterone acetate Antara is given free by the government. it is given 150 mg once in three months IM injection.

Highyeild:

Mechanism of Action: Thickening cervical mucus Preventing ovulation Antara is given free by the government. it is given 150 mg once in three months IM injection. What if a client misses her dose as per the due date? Injectable contraceptives can be given: Up to 2 weeks prior to the assigned date of dose; Or Up to 4 weeks post the assigned date If the due date exceeds by 4 weeks, a dose can be given immediately (after ruling out pregnancy), along with a backup method (condom) to be used for the next 7 days. DMPA -Side Effects of DMPA Irregular bleeding/poor cycle control (Most common side effect) The occasional phase of amenorrhea Weight gain Prolonged infertility after its use (Ovulation begins 6-12 months after the last injection) therefore, is not suitable for women planning for pregnancy in the near future. Decreased bone mass (after prolonged use), so women should be advised to use calcium supplementation. Chhaya is also given free by the Indian government it is a once-a-week pill . Centchroman or ormeloxifene is a synthetic nonsteroidal, non hormonal oral contraceptive pill. The drug has been developed by the central drug research Institute, Lucknow .It has been released under NATIONAL FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMME as Chhaya (previously called saheli ) It is given 30 mg twice a week for the first 12 weeks followed by once a week MOA: It prevents implantation by causing Endometrial changes. It can also be used as a postcoital pill at a dose of 60 mg within 24 hours of unprotected Side Effect: Headache Nausea and vomiting Weight gain Atypical endometrial hyperplasia with prolonged use. Atypical endometrial hyperplasia with prolonged use.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. COC pill- only MALA N is given FREE of cost NATIONAL FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMME Option B. Copper intrauterine device- only 2 devices are available under NATIONAL FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMME and are CuT 380 A (10 years) CuT 375 (5 years) Option D . Etonorgestrel-containing subdermal implant- are expensive.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female was your regular patient who was taking oral contraceptive pills for the past 3 months. She missed one pill on day 15 regarding which she get anxious as she had sex with her partner the day before yesterday. She visited you. What will be your advice to her?

options.label: A
options.text: You will ask her to throw the pack and use backup for the next 7 days.

options.label: B
options.text: Undergo the pregnancy test first and then start a new pack.

options.label: C
options.text: No need to worry, take 2 pills the next day and continue the same schedule.

options.label: D
options.text: Take 2 pills the next day and continue the same schedule with backup for 7 days.

questions.correct_answer: C. No need to worry, take 2 pills the next day and continue the same schedule.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

No need to worry, take 2 pills the next day and continue the same schedule. In the given scenario, the patient has missed one pill. Hence there is no need to worry. You can ask the patient to take 2 pills the next day and continue the same schedule. No need to use a backup for 7 days.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - no need to throw the pack and use backup for 7 days. Option B - no need to undergo pregnancy test and start a new pack. Option D - take two pills on next day and continue the same schedule, and no need for backup.

questions.text: A 30-year-old p1 female came to your OPD with concerns regarding missing 2 pills on day 20. She denies having sexual intercourse with her husband for the last 2 weeks as he was out on a business trip. What will be your advice to her?

options.label: A
options.text: Take 2 pills on each of the next two days and then continue the same schedule. No backup is required.

options.label: B
options.text: Start a new pack and discard the previous one. Use backup for 7 days.

options.label: C
options.text: Start a new pack without any break and no use of backup for 7 days.

options.label: D
options.text: Take a pregnancy test and start a new pack with a break of 7 days.

questions.correct_answer: B. Start a new pack and discard the previous one. Use backup for 7 days.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Start a new pack and discard the previous one. Use backup for 7 days. In the given clinical scenario, the female missed 2 pills in 3rd week e. Day 20. So, in this case, she should discard the rest of the pack and start a new pack without a break. She should use backup for the next 7 days to avoid pregnancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A -Take 2 pills on each of the next two days and then continue the same schedule is done if 2 pills were missed in the first week and backup is required for the next 7 days. Option: C - start a new pack without any break and no use of backup for 7 days is a wrong statement as the backup is used for the next 7 days. Option: D - take a pregnancy test and start a new pack with a break of 7 days is not needed, as she did not have intercourse with her husband.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with 2 pills missed during the 1st week of her menstrual cycle. She was concerned and hence she has to attend your regular opd to seek further advice. You tell her not to worry as she did not have sexual intercourse with her partner and ask her to:

options.label: A
options.text: Take two pills each of the next two days and continue the schedule. Use backup for the next 7 days.

options.label: B
options.text: Take 2 pills each of the next two days and continue the schedule thereafter without the use of any backup.

options.label: C
options.text: Start a new pack and discard the rest of the pack. Use backup for the next 7 days.

options.label: D
options.text: Start a new pack with a break of 7 days in which she can use backup.

questions.correct_answer: A. Take two pills each of the next two days and continue the schedule. Use backup for the next 7 days.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Take two pills each of the next two days and continue the schedule. Use backup for the next 7 days. In the given clinical scenario, as the female has missed 2 pills in week 1 of her cycle, she just needs to take 2 pills for the next two days and then continue the same pack with backup for the next 7 days or avoid sexual intercourse.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. - take 2 pills each of the next two days and continue the schedule thereafter without the use of any backup is a wrong statement as backup should be used. Option: C. - start a new pack and discard the rest of the pack. Use backup for the next 7 days is not done in this case. Option: D. - start a new pack with a break of 7 days in which she can use backup is a wrong statement.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female regularly uses oral contraceptive pills for 2 months now. She was undergoing a stressful period due to the demise of her father. She was not able to cope with this stress. During this period she forgot to take her pills last week. As soon as she remembers this, she visited her gynecologist. She also tells her about having intercourse with her fiancé in the previous week. What should be the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask her to throw the previous pack and start a new one with backup for 7 days.

options.label: B
options.text: Do a urine pregnancy test before further taking any contraception

options.label: C
options.text: Start a new pack with a gap of 7 days and use backup in this period

options.label: D
options.text: Continue the same pack and backup for the next 7 days.

questions.correct_answer: B. Do a urine pregnancy test before further taking any contraception
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Do a urine pregnancy test before further taking any contraception In the given clinical scenario, the female has missed pills in the last week and also has a h/o intercourse with her fiancé in that week, so the next step should be to do a urine pregnancy test and then start with contraception. If the urine pregnancy test comes out to be negative , then we can start her on a new pack and use backup for 7 days, while discarding the rest of the pills in the previous packet.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - ask her to throw the previous pack and start a new one with backup for 7 days should be done after the upt , hence the first step is upt. Option: C. - start a new pack with a gap of 7 days and use backup in this period is a wrong statement. Option: D. - continue the same pack and backup for the next 7 days is also not done in this case.

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl who is sexually active with her boyfriend is a regular user of oral combined pills. She is very regular with her pills and never misses one. Being a hostler, she frequently eats outside and due to this she suffered from an episode of vomiting , diarrhea for a period of 3-4 days. What she should do in order to prevent pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: No need to do anything as she is taking her pills regularly.

options.label: B
options.text: Gastroenteritis causes malabsorption and hence she should be treated as a case of missed pills and backup should be used for the next 7 days.

options.label: C
options.text: She should start a new pack without any backup.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above.

questions.correct_answer: B. Gastroenteritis causes malabsorption and hence she should be treated as a case of missed pills and backup should be used for the next 7 days.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastroenteritis causes malabsorption and hence she should be treated as a case of missed pills and backup should be used for the next 7 days. In the given scenario, despite taking pills regularly, she needs backup for the next 7 days as the pills will not be absorbed properly due to vomiting episodes. Hence the most appropriate answer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - no need to do anything as she is taking her pills regularly is a wrong statement. Option C - she can start a new pack but with a backup of 7 days, hence option c is a wrong statement.
